fate: Service discontinued on 2017-12-15 after usage declines amid mobile and social messaging shifts.
summary: AOL’s pioneering instant-messaging service (Buddy List, away messages) launched in 1997 and shut down in 2017.
overview_md:
**AOL Instant Messenger (AIM)** was one of the defining chat clients of the dial-up and early broadband era. Launched in **1997**, it popularized the **Buddy List**, distinctive **screen names**, and the culture of **away messages**—tiny personal status notes that doubled as micro-blogs. AIM supported one-to-one and group chats, file transfers, and “Direct Connect,” and it colocated a huge youth and college audience in shared **chat rooms**. For many U.S. users, hearing the “door open” sound meant friends were online.

AIM rode AOL’s brand and distribution to dominance in the early 2000s, and its private **OSCAR** protocol (and developer-friendly **TOC** gateway) made it a hub for third-party clients. But the landscape shifted: **SMS**, social networks, and later mobile-first apps (iMessage, WhatsApp, Facebook Messenger) pulled conversations away; multi-protocol desktops (Trillian, Pidgin) commoditized the client; and the move from PCs to smartphones weakened AOL’s installed base. Attempts to modernize—new UIs, social feeds, and a 2012 relaunch—couldn’t reverse the trend.

In **October 2017** AOL announced AIM’s end, and the service shut down on **December 15, 2017**. AIM’s legacy lives on in the language of status, presence, and group chat that modern messengers—and corporate chat tools—still use today.

timeline.text: AIM launches as a standalone instant-messaging client separate from the AOL desktop.
Early-2000s peak era: Buddy List, away messages, and chat rooms become mainstream in the U.S.
“AIM Triton” client released with tabbed IM and voice/video; struggles with performance and adoption.
AIM relaunch focuses on a cleaner interface and simplified messaging amid rising mobile competitors.
Service shut down following AOL’s October 6 announcement ending AIM.
